data.title: AssetsManager bug
Scaffold mobile project breaks FDT
data.body:
Using named nested functions and named function declaration in event handler assignment breaks the FDT.. 

More about it here : 

http://forum.starling-framework.org/topic/anonymous-functions-vs-named-functions-in-starling-mobile-scaffold-demos

Josh has suggested a nice alternative (arguments.callee) to a named function.. so it could be implemented with a anonymous function as well..

data.title: Unload specific folder assets
data.body:
Hi, I'm using a custom loader / unloader for the assets on my app and I'm missing an "unloader by folder" function on the master branch of Starling. I thought it might be useful, this is what I'm using so far:

https://gist.github.com/cgascons/9e38038b289fcaec3c5b

data.title: AssetManager's queue empty ?(isQueueEmpty())
data.body:
Hi, I'm using AssetManager altogether with my custom code on each Screen of the application to load/unload all the necessary assets per screen and per component. There are some specific cases when some components have been already loaded and I have to check if the mRawAssets lenght is > 0. I had to switch that variable to protected and created a new 'isQueueEmpty' function on my custom AssetManager. Would be possible to add this method on the AssetManager class?

Cheers!

data.title: [Bug] Multitouch breaks after 5 touches
data.body: Not sure about other devices, but on iOS you can touch and release with up to 5 fingers at once (Using TouchPhase). Though the moment you touch with a 6th finger, all fingers become released (as if they all released off the screen at once)

data.title: Bug in AssetManager.as
Bug in applyClipRect, Starling version 1.4
Dispose Starling with a Texture pending in AssetManager
data.body:
Hi!

I found a bug in AssetManager class.

If you load the queue and dispose the Starling instance after you had purged the AssetManager, then the Texture.empty method throw a MissingContextError.

The problem is that when the AssetManager is purged, the internal loader isn't stopped and disposed (removing event listeners).

Kind Regards!

data.title: Partial flash.events.IEventDispatcher implementation
data.body:
The following changes allow starling.events.EventDispatcher to implement flash.events.IEventDispatcher.

A few important warnings:

1) The capture phase is not implemented. addEventListener() and removeEventListener() name the argument `notSupported` to try to make this clear. Currently, it is completely ignored, but we might consider throwing a runtime error if this argument is set to true.

2) Priorities are not supported. addEventListener() and removeEventListener() name the argument `notSupported2` to try to make this clear. Currently, it is completely ignored, but we might consider throwing a runtime error if this argument is set to any value but 0.

3) Weak references are not supported. addEventListener() and removeEventListener() name the argument notSupported3 to try to make this clear. Currently, it is completely ignored, but we might consider throwing a runtime error if this argument is set to true.

For all three of the "notSupported" arguments, a quick line in the documentation should also help make it abundantly clear that they're not supported.

4) dispatchEvent() requires a flash.events.Event instance. Since flash.events.Event has properties that starling.events.EventDispatcher cannot change, it must throw a runtime error if it receives an argument that isn't a starling.events.Event or a subclass of it. Similar to the items above, I feel that a note in the documentation should clear things up if the runtime error isn't clear enough.

The following new features have been added:

1) Events may be cancelable. I added a cancelable argument at the end of the constructor, fromPool() function and reset() function. preventDefault() and isDefaultPrevented() are also implemented. dispatchEvent() and dispatchEventWith() return a Boolean to indicate if the event was cancelled, since IEventDispatcher defines that in the signature for dispatchEvent().

2) I exposed the eventPhase getter to indicate if its "at target" or bubbling.

3) Events are not cloned when they bubble, but starling.events.Event overrides the clone() function properly. I've heard that some people like to call clone() to redispatch events sometimes, so it makes sense to have it implemented since flash.events.Event defines it.

This change offers the following additional advantages:

1) Unless they specifically need to reference a property of starling.events.Event that isn't on flash.events.Event (that's only the data property, and there's a good solution for accessing that without importing starling.events.Event), people can simply import flash.events.Event most of the time, which gets rid of the requirement to use the fully-qualified class names when flash.events.Event is needed with other dispatchers in the same class. This is probably the most common class name conflict with native Flash classes, so it should actually help a lot.

Event listeners can simply accept flash.events.Event instead of starling.events.Event. If someone needs the data property, they can use the two-argument signature on their listeners:

```
function listener(event:Event, data:Object):void
```

The data argument can be strongly typed too, so it's better than calling the data getter on the event since that's always typed as Object.

For dispatching pooled events with dispatchEventWith(), the type constants on flash.events.Event work just as well as the constants on starling.events.Event since they're simply Strings. There shouldn't be any reason to call dispatchEvent() with a starling.events.Event, since you lose the advantages of pooling, so no one should need to import starling.events.Event for that either.

If someone continues to import starling.events.Event in new or existing code, it will continue to work the same way as before. That change won't break anything, and new code can benefit from importing flash.events.Event instead.

2) Starling and Feathers will work better in MXML since MXML requires IEventDispatcher to use some of its important features.

I feel like advantage 1 is the big one, but advantage 2 will make many Feathers users happy.

This should not break most existing code. If someone overrides addEventListener(), removeEventListener(), dispatchEvent(), or dispatchEventWith(), they will need to change the signature. I do this in a couple of places in Feathers, but it's an easy change. I doubt that many other people are adding overrides as such a low level.

What do you think?

data.title: TextField exception : Error #2015: Invalid BitmapData
data.body:
https://github.com/PrimaryFeather/Starling-Framework/blob/master/starling/src/starling/text/TextField.as#L277

``` as3
renderText:var bitmapData:BitmapData = new BitmapData(width, height, true, 0x0);
```

In some cases width and/or height are 0: new TextField(1, 1, ''); and it crashes but should show nothing.

```
[Fault] exception, information=ArgumentError: Error #2015: Invalid BitmapData.
```

Starling.current.stage.drawToBitmapData has a bug after change orientation on iPad.

data.title: FragmentFilters Interface
data.body:
Hi Daniel,

the last weeks I got lost somehow in writing FragmentFilters and I recognized that some Filters will only be possible with overriding the render function. (That recently came up with a 2.5D Filter, ... I know, bad idea ... but will also be an issue with the BloomFilter I had in mind)

Unfortunately overriding is not working well, since a lot of private variables/functions are used in your render/renderPasses functions. My workaround was disposing the filter right in the subclass's constructor and adding almost a complete copy of the FragmentFilter super class to my subclass, which is obviously bad. But I couldn't find a better way to make it work without customizing starling, which would make the filters useless for others.

So I'd like to ask whether you could implement a IFragmentFilter interface to Starling 1.4 or at least change the private functions/vars to protected, which would also be working, but as I guess be less efficient. What ever you like best. That would be really awesome.

Thanks in advance

Michael

data.title: Resetting of index and vertex data implemented
data.body:
In the dispose call the index and vertex data is now reset. When disposed before this would never decrease the index and vertex data so if a reference to the QuadBatch still existed (for example being reused in RenderSupport) then unnecessary data could hang around and cause a build up of memory.

Clearing this should not be too expensive performance wise as dispose is not called that often on QuadBatches in general.

Also I nulled out the index and vertex buffers as it was possible that dispose could be called on them when they were already disposed

data.title: Change to use a single QuadBatch
data.body:
During development I found memory issues in this class due to the amount of QuadBatches that were being created with the associated Index and Vertex buffers. I have changed this to only use a single QuadBatch as there is no need to have multiple QuadBatches as the QuadBatch itself will grow its own index and vertex buffers as needed and keep them to the largest used size. So it is wasteful to have extra QuadBatches for this purpose. I have not noticed any performance decrease with this method, in fact there might even be a very small increase in performance.

I also added a function to dispose of the QuadBatch (disposeQuadBatch()) that is called by the user to free the large index and vertex buffers that can accumulate in the QuadBatch.

data.title: Fixed TouchProcessor was dispatching only updated touches (issue #387)
data.body:
This is my fix for issue #387 (see issue for discussion).  This fixed touch problems in the large project I ported from 1.3 to 1.4, and I believe this problem is a typo introduced during TouchProcessor refactoring.

Sorry for the duplicate issue - the pull request created it automatically.

data.title: 1.4 TouchProcessor dispatches TouchEvents with only changed touches (not all touches as in 1.3)
data.body:
The TouchProcessor in 1.4 dispatches TouchEvents with only the updated Touches:

```
//  @param touches:   a list of all touches that have changed just now.
var touchEvent:TouchEvent = new TouchEvent(TouchEvent.TOUCH, touches, shiftDown, ctrlDown);
```

Whereas in 1.3 it dispatches the entire list of active Touches:

```
var touchEvent:TouchEvent = 
  new TouchEvent(TouchEvent.TOUCH, mCurrentTouches, mShiftDown, mCtrlDown); 
```

I believe this is a bug becuase
- it significantly changes how TouchEvents should be handled (the large project I ported from 1.3 is not working)
- it's undocumented in the changelog
- in [this thread](http://forum.starling-framework.org/topic/multi-touch-issue-sample-code-included) Daniel states:

> ...the touch event always contains a LIST (Vector.<Touch>) of all touches on the screen.

We are working on Firefly Framework http://firefly.in4ray.com/ and for our new version we need ability to manually  restore TextureBase object in textures that will be used by our Texture State managment functionality. Please merge if it acceptable for you.

Thanks,
in4ray team.

data.title: Get VertexData from QuadBatch
data.body:
It would be great if it would be possible to get the vertexdata from a QuadBatch in a similar way like a Quad. Either through a getter and/or a copy function. Or just setting it to protected like in the Quad class.
This have been a major issue for me when developing an extension where I need to extend the QuadBatch.

data.title: isStateChange error when using blend modes and non-textured quads
Custom TouchProcessors can't access to Touch internals
data.body:
Just realized I commented on a commit rather than opening an issue: https://github.com/PrimaryFeather/Starling-Framework/commit/a83d3537eff90b13bd9936bb4ab48d8b61cb8779#commitcomment-3862947

The gist: because Touch's internals are... visibility-internal, TouchProcessor subclasses can't really perform any custom Touch dispatching. I'm wondering if (most of) Touch's `internal` members can be made public.

data.title: Added support for Domain Memory and fast memory access
data.body:
I added support for using Domain Memory, and the fast memory access opcodes, in the byte array version of Starling. The pieces include:
- Converted the VertexData class so that all instances use references to a single global ByteArray, instead of creating a separate array for each one
- Wrote a memory manager that allocates sub-ranges of the global array for each VertexData instance, and manages operations such freeing them, re-allocating them, and growing the global heap when it's full.
- Converted all byte array accesses to use the fast avm2.intrinsics.memory operations

I've benchmarked using the built-in Starling-Demo-Web benchmark, and the difference is startling:

Before: 890 objects in debug mode, 7870 in release mode
After: 1050 objects in debug mode, 12500 in release mode

In fact this is more than a little surprising, I'd appreciate a second set of eyes on this.

Please let me know what you think. I'd be happy to comment and clean up more, to make it more production ready.

data.title: Error: Comparison method violates its general contract!
data.body:
Hello, I'm using the last version of Starling from Github. I need some extra features available in the last version of the Framwork. I got this warning when I compile my game for the first time. 
\src\starling\textures\ConcreteTexture.as(166): col: 21 Warning: Function value used where type Boolean was expected.  Possibly the parentheses () are missing after this function reference.
Then when i try to recompile the game for the second time I got this error: 
Error: Comparison method violates its general contract!
Build halted with errors (fcsh).
(fcsh)
Done(1)
Any ideas ? Thanks

data.title: Unexpected AssetManager BitmapFont naming behavior.
data.body:
It seems AssetManager when loading AngelCode XML BitmapFonts gets it's font name directly from the font.info.@face XML attribute. 

In GlyphDesigner, this value is the name the font that was the base for the Bitmap font (e.g. "Verdana").  This makes loading of fonts based on the same typeface impossible without manual editing, they over-write each other.  It also does not allow for the loading via enqueueWithName().

The simple fix for me was to modify AssetManager's loadQueue() processXML() function from

TextField.registerBitmapFont(new BitmapFont(fontTexture, xml));

to

TextField.registerBitmapFont(new BitmapFont(fontTexture, xml),name);

I would have attached a pull request bug fix for this, but it would break people who are expecting the current behavior.  Not sure how you want this handled.

Rick

data.title: Render Texture not working
RenderTexture not working
Add an optional ChannelMask property to starling.display.DisplayObject
data.body:
This is a minor feature request to possibly add in the future, but inspired by the idea of trying to implement 'packed' BitmapFonts as described and shown in the video here:

http://forum.starling-framework.org/topic/does-starling-bitmapfont-not-support-bmfonts-multiple-channel-feature

One obvious core feature to consider supporting this might be to add an optional
'channelMask' property to starling.display.DisplayObject
which would offer the values:
ChannelMask.NONE (default)
ChannelMask.RED
ChannelMask.GREEN
ChannelMask.BLUE
ChannelMask.ALPHA

which would essential filter/mask activate only the rendering of a specific channel of a texture during rendering. 
I would think this would work just like all the other state change checks meaning that a single state could be batched as long as objects share the same channel mask property.
(not sure if a bitmask and multiple channels active at a time would work or be beneficial either...)

One could imagine this being the only required 'internal' feature of Starling for someone to implement the packed per-channel BitmapFont data as implemented.

Could this end up being a fairly minimal impact addition if everyone current was just using the default ChannelMask.NONE?

Besdies packed BitmapFont usage, could there be other benefits and uses of packing data within individual channels of a texture and selectively activating only certain channels during rendering?

Just an idea and feature I wanted to throw out there if it were relatively easy to add to Starling and its AGAL uses.

data.title: BGRA_PACKED causes Texture format mismatch in Textfield with fp 11.7
data.body: I'm using air sdk 3.7 and flash player 11.7. but fb will report Error #3675: Texture format mismatch in textfield because the format is bgraPacked4444. I don't know why. fp 11.7 was supposed to support it.
